conclusion: All four shadows are cast by the same elevated light source.

premise: The light source moves directly backward (away from the objects but at the same height).
conclusion: The rays striking the objects become more oblique with respect to the table surface.

premise: The rays striking the objects become more oblique with respect to the table surface.
conclusion: Oblique lighting makes every shadow (A, B, C, D) stretch away from its parent object and become longer.

premise: The light source moves along the same line.
conclusion: The directions of the shadows on the table do not change significantly—what mainly changes is their length.

premise: The farther an object is from the light as compared with its height above the table, the larger (longer) its shadow becomes.
conclusion: All objects experience this proportionally, so their relative shadow sizes stay roughly the same.

premise: The light source moves backward above the objects.
conclusion: Shadows A, B, C, and D will all slide slightly forward on the slab (i.e., in the direction opposite the light’s motion) and will each become noticeably longer/larger while keeping approximately the same orientations and relative sizes to one another.
